Case_Transcript: Gumshoe: After securing the suspect, I examined the scene of the crime with my own eyes.
Phoenix: And did you find any evidence?
Gumshoe: Now, now, don't jump the gun on me, pal.
Gumshoe: Just listen. I'm getting to the good part!
Phoenix: (I got a bad feeling about this...)
Gumshoe: I found a memo written on a piece of paper next to the victim's body!
Phoenix: Just because you found it next to the body doesn't mean the victim wrote it!
Gumshoe: Ho hoh! Then who did write it, smarty-pants?
Phoenix: Wh-who? Um...
Phoenix: Th-the killer! Anyone can see that!
Gumshoe: Hoh.
Gumshoe: You're saying the killer wrote her OWN name!? Buddy, please!
Phoenix: She was framed!
Edgeworth: Hold on.
Edgeworth: If that's the case, where's your evidence?
Phoenix: Ah... (Urk!)
Edgeworth: Hah! I guess that was a bit of a tall order for you.
Edgeworth: Those without evidence shouldn't open their mouths, Mr. Wright.
Gumshoe: Yeah, pal!
Phoenix: (Argh...!)
Edgeworth: Well, Detective? Tell us what was written on that memo you found.
Gumshoe: On it, the word "Maya" was written clearly in blood!
Phoenix: Do you have proof it was Mia who wrote that!?
Gumshoe: Of course I do, pal!
Phoenix: (Uh oh... he sounded pretty confident. This might not be good...)
Gumshoe: Lab test results showed that the blood was the victim's!
Phoenix: What kind of "tests" were these again?
Gumshoe: Huh? What kind? Umm... well...
Gumshoe: I hear they take the, um, little bits in the blood, the... er... hemo... hemogl...
Gumshoe: Hermo... goblins... hobgob... Er...? Herma-goblin bobbin...
Gumshoe: I-I refuse to testify on this matter, pal!
Gumshoe: I'm no expert on blood tests!
Judge: Yes, that was quite clear. You may continue with your testimony.
Gumshoe: Th-thanks, pal. I mean Your Honor Sir.
Edgeworth: Detective Gumshoe.
Gumshoe: Y-yeah?
Edgeworth: I look forward to your next evaluation. As should you.
Gumshoe: ...O-oh...
Phoenix: (That was a mess...)
Gumshoe: Right! Where was I?
Gumshoe: Also, there was blood found on the victim's finger!
Phoenix: On which hand was the bloody finger, Detective?
Gumshoe: The right hand!
Phoenix: (Hmm... she WAS right handed...)
Gumshoe: Hah hah hah! Nice try!
Phoenix: (Uh oh... I guess it wasn't too hard to see what I was getting at there.)
Gumshoe: Before she died, the victim wrote the killer's name!
Phoenix: Detective Gumshoe!
Phoenix: Do you get a lot of cases where the victim actually writes the killer's name?
Gumshoe: Sure! It happens all the time in books and the movies!
Phoenix: This isn't a movie, Detective.
Gumshoe: Oof!
Phoenix: Let's talk about reality, shall we?
Gumshoe: Umm... I guess, I haven't heard of many cases... no.
Phoenix: Don't you find it a little odd that the victim would write down a name?
Phoenix: Especially the name of her own sister?
Gumshoe: Ah, yeah, actually, you got a point, pal.
Edgeworth: Stop right there.
Edgeworth: The witness's opinion on the matter is irrelevant!
Edgeworth: The facts are clear: the victim wrote down the name of the accused...
Edgeworth: The victim told us the name of her killer!
Judge: Order! Order!
Phoenix: (That didn't go so well...)
Gumshoe: Th-that's right! What he said!
Phoenix: (That's his whole testimony...)
Phoenix: (Okay, there has to be a contradiction in there somewhere. Let's find it!)
evidences: ATTORNEY'S BADGE: No one would believe I was a defense attorney if I didn't carry this.. UI description: The item is a small, circular, metallic object, predominantly gold in color with a shiny finish. It features a raised, ridged border resembling scalloped edges encircling a slightly recessed center. Within this central area, there is an embossed symbol, possibly representing scales or stylized wings. The object appears thick and three-dimensional, catching the light on its polished surfaces and edges. It looks like a pin or badge meant for identification.

MIA'S AUTOPSY REPORT: Time of death: 9/5 at 9:00 PM. Cause: single blunt force trauma. Death was instantaneous.. UI description: The evidence displayed is a standard-sized, tan-colored manila envelope. It appears to be made of paper and is oriented diagonally. The envelope is sealed using a traditional string-and-button closure; two dark, circular buttons are visible, with a string wrapped around them to secure the flap. There are no visible labels, writing, or damage on the surface shown.

MAYA'S CELL PHONE: Holds a conversation between the Chief and Maya. (September 5, 9:27 AM. Maya: Mia! What's up? You haven't called in a while. Mia: Well, actually there's something I want you to hold on to for me. Maya: Again? What is it this time? Mia: It's... a clock. It's made to look like that statue, 'The Thinker.' And it tells you the time! Ah... I should probably tell you, the clock isn't talking right now. Maya: Huh? It's not working? That's lame! Mia: I had to take the clockwork out, sorry. I put some papers inside it instead. Maya: Papers? Is that the evidence, then? Mia: I'll leave that one up to your imagination. See you tonight at nine.). UI description: An older model, non-flip cell phone, primarily purple or violet in color. It features a small, dark rectangular screen on the upper portion and a light grey keypad below with multiple small, rectangular buttons arranged in rows. A short antenna extends from the top right corner. A matching purple wrist strap, looped through a hole on the top left, hangs beside the phone. The phone has a somewhat bulky, rounded design and appears to be made of plastic.

ATTORNEY'S BADGE: No one would believe I was a defense attorney if I didn't carry this.. UI description: The evidence is a circular, metallic gold badge or pin. It has a thick appearance with a prominently ridged or fluted outer edge, giving it a textured border. The central area features an embossed symbol, though its precise details are somewhat obscured by the lighting and angle; it seems complex, possibly depicting scales or stylized characters. The surface has a polished, metallic sheen and appears to be in good condition, without any visible scratches or damage.

MIA'S AUTOPSY REPORT: Time of death: 9/5 at 9:00 PM. Cause: single blunt force trauma. Death was instantaneous.. UI description: The evidence displayed is a standard, tan-colored manila envelope. It is rectangular and appears to be made of paper. On the side shown, there are two dark, circular buttons part of a string-and-button closure mechanism, indicating this is likely the back of the envelope. The string itself is wrapped around the buttons, suggesting the envelope is sealed. There is no visible writing, address, or other markings on the envelope itself.

MAYA'S CELL PHONE: Holds a conversation between the Chief and Maya. (September 5, 9:27 AM. Maya: Mia! What's up? You haven't called in a while. Mia: Well, actually there's something I want you to hold on to for me. Maya: Again? What is it this time? Mia: It's... a clock. It's made to look like that statue, 'The Thinker.' And it tells you the time! Ah... I should probably tell you, the clock isn't talking right now. Maya: Huh? It's not working? That's lame! Mia: I had to take the clockwork out, sorry. I put some papers inside it instead. Maya: Papers? Is that the evidence, then? Mia: I'll leave that one up to your imagination. See you tonight at nine.). UI description: The evidence is a somewhat dated, candy bar-style cell phone. Its main casing is a vibrant metallic purple or pink color. Below the dark, rectangular screen is a silver keypad with multiple small, rectangular buttons arranged in a grid. A short, stubby antenna extends from the top right corner. Attached to the top left corner is a thick, dark purple fabric wrist strap. The phone appears intact and functional, without obvious signs of damage.

GLASS SHARDS: The broken remains of a glass light stand. Broken beyond all recognition.. UI description: The evidence icon displays approximately six irregularly shaped, sharp-edged fragments. The pieces vary in size and have a light grey/white, somewhat reflective appearance, suggesting broken glass. Some fragments possess a slight curvature. They are depicted scattered across a grey background within the evidence slot.

THE THINKER: The murder weapon. Looks like a statue, but it's actually a clock. Made by Larry Butz.. UI description: The evidence is a small, metallic statue resembling Rodin's "The Thinker." The figure is depicted in a seated, thinking pose, colored in a bronze or brass tone. It is mounted on a square, metallic grey base. The front of the base features a small, dark, rectangular slot or recessed area. The statue appears intact and relatively small, suitable for placement on a desk or table.

WIRETAP: Found in Miss May's hotel room.. UI description: The item consists of a small, black, rectangular plastic box. Two flexible black wires emerge from one end of the box, loop around, and terminate in small, cylindrical, gold-colored metallic tips. The overall object appears to be a compact electronic device.

RECEIPT: A department store receipt with letters written in blood on the back.. UI description: The evidence is a slightly crumpled, roughly rectangular piece of white paper. On its surface, the name "Maya!" is written in large, thick, dripping letters using a red substance that resembles blood. The handwriting is somewhat uneven.

FLOOR PLANS: The murder scene, the Fey & Co. Law Offices.. UI description: The evidence is a single, slightly tilted square or rectangular piece of paper. It appears light gray or off-white and has a smooth, possibly slightly reflective surface. There are no visible markings, text, folds, or damage on the paper. It looks like a blank sheet.
